cons: Not a lot of opportunity to move up. Lots of lateral movement. When new positions open then generally already know who they want for the job no matter who applies.

title: Too much work too little pay
pros: Some of my coworkers were nice
cons: Overworked and underpaid. Why hire more employees when you can just squeeze the ones you currently have? You might think you’re getting paid a competitive rate, but I promise that you are not. I’m a college educated individual who felt absolutely no opportunity for growth. Not to mention these companies are systematically gentrifying and pricing out low income families all over the country.

title: Complete Waste of Two Years, Advancement is Non-Existant
pros: The team at my property was great. Solid benefits.
cons: Ladies, you know that one relationship you regret. You wasted a two years on a guy hoping that someday (SOMEDAY) he would appreciate how wonderful and talented you were, how smart you were, how much you took tasks on that he'd never had to worry about, how little you asked for in return...how much you really cared. How LOYAL you were. Welcome to my relationship with AvalonBay. If AvalonBay were a boyfriend, I should have dumped his worthless behind long ago. I interviewed with multiple years experience in property management under my belt, coming from a management role. I accepted an entry level sales position with assurances of quickly forthcoming advancement that never materialized (all the while watching non-industry, outside candidates be placed straight into management). Lots of favoritism for the corporate brown nosers at this company. Watch out for those people because they will quietly stab you in the back to look golden to management -- also to hold you down because they're terrified you'll leap-frog them a promotion. Once that happens, you can forget about any kind of advancement. As others have mentioned, if you're not a POD favorite you may as well start seeking alternate employment. Pay at AVB was always low for the respective industry but now they've introduced a sparkly new compensation program that they've billed as our opportunity to make more bonus. In short, they reduced the hourly pay of all employees by 12% (with the exception of managers, of course) in exchange for what they claim is a massive opportunity to make more bonus on leases. Best wishes to AVB hiring good talent at $13 an hour because this bonus structure only benefits the company, not the employees. And good luck finding a manager who can actually even explain the bonus calculator in a transparent way. Smoke and mirrors. What AVB's essentially done is create a culture of teams scrambling, clawing and stepping on each other to claim the best leads and making shady exceptions to get leases on the board -- I mean, if the Senior CC's going to hold out an apartment seven days instead of the mandated three, why wouldn't I? #GREAT Additionally, the bonus goals are set borderline unattainable, so corporate, who set them, is banking on one or more consultant on a team missing in any given month. What's that mean for shareholders? $$$$$ Yup. Hey investors, hope you're enjoying riding the backs of AVB livestock! Avalon employs corporate sheep for a reason. Plod along, don't ask questions, don't challenge authority, brown nose at every turn, do your manager's work, accept pay decreases with a smile. Bow to corporate. Bow to abusive residents. Get this! Our manager was so afraid to get a bad review on social media that he actually waived a person's move-out charges to get them to remove a one-star Yelp. How do you look up to or aspire to be a manager like that??? Cute for a company that benchmarks integrity as a core value, isn't it? Opportunity abounds at other PM companies...don't waste your time with Avalon unless you enjoy the corporate game as opposed to being valued for your intelligence, entrepreneurial spirit and experience.

title: Appears great on the surface
pros: The best reason to work at AvalonBay is that you'll be surrounded by kind, smart and a professional group of people. Total compensation is higher than industry standards
cons: Favoritism, indirect management style, you have to be "liked" to be respected in the organization, HR is in the best interest of management not the employees, Highly hierarchical

title: It's an investment product not a property management company!
pros: There are no pros other than Washington is an "at will" state. So you can leave any time!
cons: This isn't a company. It's a REIT . So the bottom line is they want money for their investors and THATS IT! You aren't even a human to them, you're an object. They want to make sure their "assets" - you included- are in line like good little robots so they demand access to your personal life as well. Run, don't walk, run from this investment product.

title: Love working for this company, work with lots of great people!
pros: I feel like you truly have a work-life balance with this company. It makes me enjoy coming to work. I feel it is a collaborative environment where team building plays a big role. I have met lots of employees that have left but have come back because the grass was not greener. I think that says a lot about the company.
cons: Really can't think of any.

title: GAME CHANGER
pros: Best Employer, Best Staff, and Best Schedule. Amazing Commission. 1 Hour break for every position.
cons: Hiring Process is forever!!! I Mean months, I almost forgot about a position I applied for. The benefits are Horrible. You get them all, but Health, Dental, and 401K are pointless. Just get your own company and pay out of pocket instead.

title: A good place to work
pros: The culture and the people at AvalonBay is what brought me here and what keeps me here. The work is meaningful and there is a sense of ownership.
cons: If you are not driven for continuous improvement this is not a place for you. Things keep changing and evolving and it takes a commitment to try new things and make things better.

title: Started good. Ended bad
pros: They really make you want to work there. Benefits, schedule, work life balance. All sounds great
cons: You are just a number. They are so strict on their attendance rule that they don't count for emergency situations. Promised all these great things that never happened. Talked about the spirit of caring, which I did not feel like they provided. One sided management. It is their way or the highway.

title: Solid company, always looking to improve
pros: Great benefits, team atmosphere, solid upper management. Always looking for ways to improve efficiency within the company and development is sharp and chooses great locations to live and work.
cons: There are constantly new initiatives within the company, most are good, however there are times when things are rolled out a bit prematurely and there are some growing pains that have a negative effect on employees or specific properties as things are not always beneficial to he entire company, but for the majority.

title: Slave
pros: Management starts out acting like they want to help you. But there really isn't any upward mobility. They know who they want to promote or advance into upper positions. It takes about 4 to 6 months, butin that time you will learn where you really stand.
cons: Management attitude. If you make a complaint or have a question about anyone they find is a friend.... forget a career. Even though retaliation is considered unacceptable.... management does it ALL the time. So sad to see they push associates into a non-caring attitude.

title: They almost have it perfect
pros: They have amazing benefits and give us the freedom to make on the spot decisions without repercussion. They pay well!
cons: Corporate offices need to be more interactive with boots on ground. NOT managers like myself but closer. A panel of Managers and leasing and maintenance should be in on big company changes. Some of the people making decisions have never worked on-site. This job is unique and cannot be modeled after any other.

title: 18 Years and Counting!
pros: The culture is like no other. When I started with the company, I had a career path in mind and AvalonBay helped me put that into action. I saw nothing but opportunity and still do. One of the best things about this company is their willingness to adapt and change as the world changes around us. I am proud to be part of the company that cares so much about their employees and customers!
cons: You must be willing to adapt quickly to change.

title: No Job Security!
pros: • Good for building experience in hospitality • Good for networking and meeting important people
cons: • No diversity, each property has its own culture and policies. • Do not accommodate for disabilities • No room for growth as promised. • Overwhelming scheduling. • Not unionized which means you don't have any job security. • Not allowed to accept any gratuity offers from residents which is a doorman / Concierge no no if you work in this line of business. • No work and life balance as promised. You are obligated to attend meetings on your days off. • HR & Management are usually friends & can cause a conflict of interest if you have and issues.

title: A company that cares
pros: AvalonBay has truly lived up to what their culture is. Caring for people and creating a better way to live every day. The two thing that stands out the most for me is the work / life balance I now have since joining AvalonBay and the trust they instill in their associates.
cons: Every company always has an opportunity. The only feedback I have would be AvalonBay needs to create more brand awareness. So everyone knows what ana amazing organization it is.

title: Avalon Bay all the Way!
pros: The people that work for Avalon Bay Communities really care about growing the success of one another as individuals and also the business as a whole. I have a sense that everyone deeply cares about turning in grade A work and not settling for anything but excellence from peers to management.
cons: Technology, such as slow processes within programs and devices. It would allow us all to be more efficent if these processes were more streamlined. Not bad, but not great.

title: Great Company that is Committed to being the Best
pros: Highly committed to being the very best. Tremendous amount of effort and resources are dedicated to understanding our markets and what our residents want / need. Great working environment with an emphasis on respect and genuine caring for one another. If you're a self motivated hard worker the opportunities are endless.
cons: The work load can be overwhelming at times.

title: Great Coworkers and Relaxed Environment
pros: People I work with are very nice and they are very supportive/helpful.
cons: Pay is very little for the amount/kind of work we are doing. Leasing staff in general needs to be paid more especially across different geographies. Equity is important but cost of living needs to be taken into account when setting the pay rate for each state/city.

title: The Best Company in Property Management
pros: The Growth and advancement. Tons of information to help you succeed to the next step in your career. Amazing team and Management. I've worked as a Regional Community
cons: ultant and loved every property I worked at; from AVA, eaves, Avalon and KANSO. No complaints on how your hard work is recognized.

title: Great Learning Experience, Constant Training and a Real Family Vibe
pros: Training is great at AvalonBay you are constantly assigned training its a great learning experience for a beginner in Property Management.
cons: tant Training and a Real Family Vibe

title: Great Organization
pros: Avalonbay is one of the best companies out there to work for. Company is stable, structured, and ran well. I have worked with very smart and hardworking individuals and learned a lot about both sides of the business.
cons: There is a big push for change and the never ending initiatives with no sunset strategy consumes your time enough to prevent you to do your job.

title: Amazing company to work for
pros: AvalonBay’s greatest strength is its culture and work environment. Rather than feeling lost in such a large company, I felt a sense of belonging, and that my efforts had purpose and were appreciated. The executives set the tone of no ego, which creates a culture that is both collaborative and supportive. Combining this with the resources of such a large company, AVB offers an exceptional environment to learn and grow.
cons: There are no downsides of working for AVB.

title: Talent Acquisition
pros: Company culture and work environment is great, as are the associates - genuinely nice, smart people who want to help each other and residents. Benefits are really good. You feel essential and valued as a part of the company.
cons: Workforce is pretty lean. So the workload can be substantial, but you're definitely never bored and are rewarded for your hard work.

title: Good Sales Exposure
pros: You get good training in sales and how to deal with difficult clients, You job is very rewarding helping others t find a new home
cons: Management style is very inconsistent. Be sure to ask for constant feedback so reviews don't come up as a surprise. Work life balance is also very difficult because you will work long hours and are often asked to work 6 days a week.

title: Well-rounded Company
pros: Spirit of Caring is real. Partners with American Red Cross to hold on site blood drives and offers a company match during times of disaster. Pays associates their full salary to volunteer at company-sponsored events (Habitat for Humanity builds, ForKids builds, regattas, food packing, etc.)
cons: Compensation a little low in some cases compared to market

title: Management Perspective
pros: Strong networking amongst other community managers to help support each other. Training and technology are always advancing to educate and streamline processes to make them the most efficient.
cons: Staffing sees a lot of turn over amongst technicians, often times as a manager you’ll have to jump into a technician role to keep up with workload. Upper management expects you to get all work done and remain in budget even during short staffing, all while adding on new tasks to the role.

title: Despite what they tell you, NOT a good company at all!!
pros: You might find a few people you like and could become friends with. But, that's a big "might"
cons: This is a very large corporation and you should know this coming in. Employees are numbers and this company tries very hard to say they're customer service focused, but the bottom line is just that...the bottom line. Money and making your numbers is most important!! If you're doing well, then you have to better, they tell you, because you now have to make up for the properties not doing well and when AVB makes a promise to their shareholders, about how much MORE revenue they'll make year-over-year, then gosh-darn it, they will make those numbers at all costs!! I read other reviewers commenting on the high increases they give residents. That's an understatement! They HAVE to make more and more money so residents be damned, either pay or get out!! Employees....don't like it? Then get out! HR says they "care" about employees opinions, but no way. I see the responses, on these reviews, saying how they care about our feelings and really hope we go tell someone our concerns. Do that and your a gonner! Once you're pegged as being a problem, they start the documentation trail (written counselings) and then you're out. And I've seen people comment about this being a gossip friendly company. Oh boy is it!! This company should have it's own reality show. It's funny, vicious, sad and downright deplorable! And the pay....haven't even talked about that!! Have you heard about the new bonus plan. They'll scream at you about how you can "make 3-times your bonuses", but that's not true. You take a 12.5% hourly PAYCUT for this new plan too! So you make even less money (which was pretty low even in this industry) and you MAY or MAY NOT make your goals. If your goal is to get 8 leases and you get 3 then your get NOTHING!!! And this is happening all over the place. So, now they've turned us into money-grubbing back-stabbing nutballs trying to steal leases from each other. It's really disgusting! I wonder who got a VP position for coming up with that program! Do yourself a favor and keep perusing other companies on this site. AvalonBay is NOT the one you want to be with.

title: Excellent company to work for!!
pros: The company takes care of you as an associate. They truly care. They will make changes if something is not working to benefit the associates of the company.
cons: A little more communication on new roll outs or policy's. Things are constantly changing, which is not a bad thing, but more of a heads up would be beneficial.

title: Great culture and atmosphere of collaboration
pros: After about 3 months with AVB, I took stock and confirmed what a great company I'd joined. There is a REAL culture of collaboration and decent people here. Now several years later I continue to feel the same.
cons: I wish my commute was shorter, but the benefits of working for AVB make it worth it.

title: Good and bad experiences.
pros: Large company with local support staff.
cons: Elitist group at top regional / director positions that oversee the on-site managers. HR has shown that they show favoritism depending on external relationships with certain managers / directors. Not truly a transparent company.

title: Keep it moving if you have self respect
pros: Easy work (that is done on purpose so don’t have to pay you accordingly), regular schedule, decent benefit package
cons: Clique mentality worse than some 80’s high school movie. They’d rather hire unskilled know-nothings over skilled workers to save $ on payroll. They’ll keep you in your position forever without hesitation and you’re toast once you advocate for yourself

title: Great place to work!
pros: AvalonBay is an industry leader and I truly believe it's because of the amazing associates. From Senior Management to on-site teams, everyone goes above and beyond make connections and do the best job possible. The Company values (continuous improvement, spirit of caring and commitment to integrity) are very important to associates and it shows in both overall strategy and day-to-day operations.
cons: At times, the workload and lack of resources is overwhelming.

title: Could have been better
pros: 401k : matches up to 5-6% but it changes Medical/dental/vision : 7/10
cons: End of year employee reviews are a joke. Your contributions dont matter as everyone gets the same pay raise each year. It's more of a psychological approach to make employees feel good about themselves. Budgets are made a year prior for every wage increase.

title: Horrific
pros: On call Overtime, days off and to be brutally honest, THAT'S IT!
cons: Overtime, lack of training, lack of people skills within own company, lack of managerial skills, lack of team builds, career advancement, work life balance, days off, no bonuses nor tips allowed

title: Do you want low pay or your foot in the door...
pros: Do you want low pay or your foot in the door? You can gain experience anywhere for a lot more pay. Ultimately you have to decide what's more important to you. I recommend UDR or Essex.
cons: • Pay could be a lot better. Underpaid compared to industry standards in addition to the amount of accounting/administrative duties. • management have you doing variance reports and take credit for your work. (NY market does not do variance reports) • Residents can verbally abuse and physically assault (lease violations) staff and upper management will continue to roll out the red carpet for them. • No work life balance despite what you’re told. • I witnessed all maintenance team members work off the clock to accommodate residents and their general manager is aware of it, but pretends to be blind to labor laws. • Told countless times that I am great leader, intelligent, doer, problem solver etc. etc. But never told me about areas of opportunities. Yet told his boss who then told me. (interesting) • Pretending to like managers, if you do not nod and agree with non-sense, you’re likely to be placed in the out-group and labeled as a trouble maker. • Human resources/regional staff members are facebook friends with front line workers, throwing their names in career advancement opportunities because they have access to ops managers, preventing advancement opportunities for others who work really hard from getting ahead. • Forced to have fun! • Refusing to have lunch with managers will place you in the out-group and labeled as a trouble maker. • Counterproductive busy work • Some managers are allowed to be offensive, rude, disrespectful, intrusive, and annoying and its acceptable behaviors. And others cannot simply be left alone to work and be productive. • Pay can be a lot better. • Overworked • Not appreciated • Overlooked • Constantly hearing about your strengths and weaknesses through your bosses’ boss. Pushed out of the organization because I'm in school and encouraged to pursue another career. Told countless times by management despite my contributions, awards, professionalism etc.

title: Community Manager
pros: It's been rewarding working for Avalon Bay. There's been a lot of effort from the corporate level for the the well being of the associates. I have enjoyed the culture, people that I have worked with over the years and the emphasis on associate development.
cons: There are cons at every work place, as long as you enjoy what you do it's hard to focus on the negative.

title: AvalonBay is the best!
pros: AvalonBay is the best property management company out there. I feel appreciated and enjoy the work I do. I feel honored to be part of such a great organization and I would recommend (and have) to anyone!
cons: The only thing I can think of in terms of improvement is how associates are compensated. I would like to see my salary truly reflect my loyalty and dedication to the company.

title: Great Company to Work For
pros: The people that work here make this company great. There are a lot of tenured associates and there's a reason for that. I've always experienced an exceptional level of work/life balance, and really haven't ever considered leaving after working here 7+ years because of the people and balance.
cons: The pay is a little lower than you'd expect / get at a competitor (and not always equitable among associates), and their benefits could be better.

title: Good mix
pros: Work life balance is there. Of the 6-7 companies I've worked with I find that AVB delivers fair pay for the hours worked. Having been in public accounting and corporate, this corporate job is nice. Not dull and slow like some companies, but not back breaking like public. The people are great.
cons: Not as highly paid as you could be in accounting. But you also don't work egregious hours. So take your pick.

title: Do not recommend
pros: - Buy employees lunch a lot
cons: - Not a lot of opportunity to move up in the company - Very hard to hit your goals to get your bonus - Very little time off for holidays - Required to work most Saturdays of the year - Safety concerns being an associate with there response to covid

title: Great people, great culture, and great opportunities for growth
pros: Friendly and inviting company culture. Highly skilled co-workers. Tenured and knowledgeable Executive leaders. Great strategic vision. Discount for living at an AvalonBay community. Challenging work environment with a lot of room for growth.
cons: The benefits package is good, not great. It checks the boxes but it could be better. Also, diversity at the Executive level could be better.

title: Great Company
pros: Very structured environment. Company cares about the employees and easy to get promoted. Good benefits and 401 K match is a plus.
cons: There is not much to say. I'd appreciate if the housing and the employee discounts were better. Associate housing is very strict and impersonal.

title: Overall Positive
pros: Extremely organized training process, you feel supported from the start. You get practice doing what your job will entail before arriving to your work site.
cons: Management at the work site had issues with each other that would then affect the employees. It's like you had to pick a side you were on and they would talk about each other to you. Hated being involved at all, there should be more communication to create a nicer workplace

title: The fluff on the outside hides a lack of caring for employees
pros: It's an easy company to work for as long as you show up and do what you are supposed to.
cons: HR teams in multiple regions dismiss serious offenses (sexual harassment, anti-semitic comments, homophobic comments, sexist comments, lack of equal opportunity); in fact, managers who check all of these boxes as an offender end up getting promoted. Also the company had no empathy for employees needing COVID vaccine exemptions, and went through a third party company opposed to their own HR team, resulting in associates not being recognized as actual human beings and inhumane terminations.

title: Supportive culture, endless room for professional growth.
pros: The work life balance is fantastic. Avalonbay puts on events for their associates every quarter of the year. They want their employees to be successful at their jobs and reward them for performance.
cons: The company values their employees. management does provide recognitition for outstanding associates who demonstrate they are meeting goals and helping the company grow.

title: A Sinister Corporation
pros: if you enjoy being treated like a child and awarded for nodding your head yes when asked, it is a stable job
cons: -The product (apartments) are cheap and terribly made. Avalon uses the bottom of the barrel contractors and material -You are bombarded as an employee with "vote us #1" on glassdoor while passive threats of your employment security are made if you don't oblige. -Very political and begs loyalty to "the man. Your only way "up" is selling your soul to the corporate lies they spew to their prospects, residents and employee's -Whitewashed and conservative -A clinical number of seminars are held to remind you how special it is to work for Avalon, while coercing you to go far beyond the responsibilities you were initially hired for. This is to show your loyalty to the company and also their way of cheap, stretched labor. -PAID NOTHING comparable to competitors. -Good luck getting in touch with HR or someone concerned to help you. -You won't sleep at night when you realize YOU are in charge of telling people their rent just went up 20%. Management doesn't care. They are sitting in their corporate cushion feeling great. Now be the good little employee and break the bad news to the family who just had a kid and can't afford the move or hike in rent. Bottom line, they have a "brush it under the table" mentality and demands complete loyalty to their corporate leaders. Their product is terribly made and they expect you to lie and deceive their customers. I did not come across one person that was truly happy working there. Hopefully, this will deter you from making the same mistake I made and what felt like a very long jail sentence.

title: Great Company!
pros: The company is very thorough with their training and support. They provide a great new hire boot camp as well as continued training and on site classes. The best part-they have associate appreciation days and sales rallies and so much more events and opportunities that allow you to network with others in the company which in return helps with the growth within the company.
cons: No Cons as of yet!

title: Industry is changing
pros: Work/life balance. Company culture has always been great. Inclusion & Diversity groups ran by associates.
cons: -Pay structure was changed at the beginning of 2020, and it has been a lot less money for high volume communities. Only small communities benefited. More work, less pay.

title: Over ten years of loving this company!
pros: The benefits are amazing as well as the promoting from within culture. This is the company to join if you are looking for a career. The team work onsite, between communities and teams and between corporate and the sites is amazing. One big family - promoting awesome places to live and work!
cons: Some locations are a bit short staffed which can be stressful at times.

title: Love the Company and People!
pros: I enjoy the Team environment that our SD region promotes! I have worked for another property management company and it just doesn't compare. AvalonBay as a company is generally moving in a forward direction at all times with technology and policies.
cons: Some of the systems are a little harder to navigate for new empployees. The benefit is that the team environment promotes new hires asking for help from their peers.

title: Need better pay/ no career growth
pros: Amazing benefits and people to work with
cons: The pay is low for the amount of work we have and they want you to do more work then what you get paid for and you have to work on every Saturday. That really sucks!

title: Such a great company!
pros: Alot of room to grow, and unlimited work enough to perfect your craft . Now read..
cons: I think the company should provide all oncall techs with better housing discount. And to all . To improve productivity and the attention necesaary to the community.

title: Customer Care Center does not care at all!
pros: The “little” people working the floor. Great teams and floor managers.
cons: Senior management is disconnected from its employees. Only care about bottom line.

title: Things have changed
pros: On site teams and benefits.
cons: The NY/Westchester leadership is a disappointment and does not live up to the "cultural norms" and "family" environment this company has promoted for so long. This includes HR, directors, and general managers. The empathetic allyship and initiaves they push are only to check boxes with no real intention of making the necessary connections. I strongly advise associates not to use "radical candor" as anything you say can and will most definitely be used against you. The company as a whole, is only concerned with its corporate citizenship as proven by its politics, ultimatums and termination of associates that were once considered heroes. An audacious move dictated by its majority stockholders under the guise of employee safety which resulted in alienation, toxicity, and low morale. The onsite teams are underpaid and over worked while expected to provide free marketing by pushing 5 star reviews for an average product with classless residents. As with all REITs, every property is ultimately for sale so there really isn't job security on a site level, especially in CT/NY/Westchester. Expect business managers who are selfish overachievers that only care about results and do not like feedback or pushback. Expect retalition disguised as false allegations and wrongful terminations. Expect mixed messaging from yes men/women who are traitorous. Expect disrespect and maltreatment from customers in sometimes unsafe enviroments with no consequences. Do not expect people managers and leaders who put their teams first. Do not expect to work at a luxury site with a clientele that will respect the staff. Do not expect a balanced family/work life as work schedules do not coincide with family needs.

title: Fake company, fake people!
pros: Not much. You get apaycheck, but you can get one elsewhere too!
cons: I work in the LA area and OMG has this company changed! A couple of years ago Avalon took over part of a company, Archstone, that did so bad it went out of business! Well, someone didn't tell the former Archstone employees this. They feel they took over Avalon and they just came in with all sorts of ideas about how to change the company. And the executives are actually allowing it. It's like they feel bad for this company, and it's crazy-paid employees, and are giving them cart blanche to do what they want. They all came in with much higher titles and higher pay and they don't know nearly as much as the current Avalon people. We all couldn't believe our eyes and ears! Major animosity going on! The executives are just out of control. What are they looking for in LA? Well, let's just say they like their "leasing girls" to be quite pretty and look darn good. Curled hair, makeup, and the kind that can 'attract new residents'. The regionalmanagers are just awful! Mean-spirited, belittling and always on you to get your numbers. It reminds me of used car sales. If you don't get your numbers, they write the heck up out of you and then will just fire you! This has happened to SEVERAL associates. It's very sad. Good people, doing thier best, but just tossed out. They want these great numbers because they want thier big bonuses. Yes, this is true. These people get big bonuses and you better not be in the way of them getting it. This company experiences so much turn over, they know they'll just find some other slob, and then work them to death. And then make them feel soooo lucky to be working for this company. They pretty much brainwash you into thinking this is the best company and you should feel so lucky. And then you aren't supposed to ask for raises or promotions. Again, very sad indeed. The LA region is a very stressful region for sure and you really have to have some major thick skin to work here. They definitely have their favorites for sure too. If you're not a 'chosen one' then run for your life.

title: Best Corporate Culture I've ever experienced
pros: Leaders are smart, thoughtful and respectful. Coworkers are genuine, friendly and congenial. Corporate Office is very clean and comfortable working environment and all technology needs are met.
cons: Work hard, do good work and your reward is... more work! And bonuses. But more work!

title: Variety of Advancement Oppurtunities
pros: I like how diverse this company is and that they're bi-coastal and different positions are available for career growth.
cons: I dislike that if someone calls out from their shift that's your relief, you have to stay at the desk until coverage is found and that's unfair because I have kids that need to picked up form daycare and I shouldn't have to be late leaving due to someone else's problem.

title: Onsite Support is Forgotten
pros: I really like most of the people I interact with at this company. Many have become friends in my personal life and the rest are fairly easy to get along with.
cons: Our onsite teams need more support. It feels like we're constantly fighting tooth and nail to make a tiny bit of progress on something that will make our jobs easier, but senior leadership refuses to listen. They're not here working onsite with us and I know several other managers have complained about the same issues, but our legitimate concerns constantly fall on deaf ears. We recently had to downsize our onsite teams in exchange for AI doing parts of our job... except AI has been less than successful and several of our processes still require human support. We've been stretched very thin with longer working hours/extended work weeks and corporate refuses to allow us to hire appropriate staffing. So far this only applies to the office side but maintenance isn't far behind. As soon as they realize they can cut corners with our maintenance team, they'll be impacted by this "skeleton crew" staffing model just as badly (if not worse) as the office has been. Lastly, the communication from other departments is terrible. This company claims to have a core value of "We Collaborate" but here's what really happens: some department from corporate makes a new company initiative that impacts onsite teams. There's a training call for the new initiative on a Tuesday. It rolls out on Wednesday. Missed the training call? Eh, you'll figure it out because SURELY someone else on your team was on the call and can support you in getting up to speed... even though they themselves had less than 24 hours to absorb the information. All in all, there is a lack of transparency and strategic planning. Corporate will just schedule another "change management" call that all of us have to dial into and get no real value from the conversation.

title: Manage a portfolio of Apartment Communities
pros: Treated like family and surrounded by true professionals. Proper work life balance. Our company's Spirit of Caring is second to none.
cons: Not really a con for me , but very fast paced and ever changing. But I thrive on that. If you love to learn and improve then take this con and make it a pro!

title: Excellent place to work!
pros: This is an amazing place to work for many reasons but the one that really surprised me was the dedication to the core values. See what our residents have to say; about 200,000 people live at AvalonBay Communities (that's about the same size as Yonkers, NY in population).
cons: Some people are in a bit of a silo, but that is improving the more people embrace Chatter and Origami.

title: Refreshing!
pros: My manager and that person's manager are incredibly invested in my success and that of what I am working on. People in the office have a sincere and obvious respect, if not love for some, for each other. I am impressed at how tenured AND happy everyone is. Opportunities abound - you just have to ask. This is a dream opportunity.
cons: Work load can be heavy, but resources are available.

title: Great employee-centric culture
pros: Employees are valued, heard and supported. You are never made to feel like a number and work/life balance is encouraged. Excellent corporate citizens both internally and externally. I am proud to work here.
cons: One's strengths can sometimes become one's weakness when taken to extremes. Our cultural norm to be thoughtful and thorough make AVB reliable and sound in judgement but can sometimes slow things down.

title: Toxic Workplace - It's All About Who You Know!
pros: Another employer with health benefits.
cons: Working onsite at communities has taken a toll on moral over the years. The RS leadership constantly makes adjustments to the leasing bonus plan, decreasing pay and incentives, while increasing the workload and reducing staff. Total disregard for "nonessential employees", such a leasing consultants, maintenance technicians, concierges, etc., while working onsite amid the global pandemic crisis as the corporate office employees and POD's work remotely and safely in the comfort of their home constantly pressuring the "nonessential employees" to do more, do better, exceed lease goals, increase NPS scores, increase Google reviews, etc. The pressure is unreal. Leasing team members are doing triple times the work in order to bring home a decent paycheck. There was once a time leasing consultants could make over $2k as a leasing bonus for 14+ leases, but now with all the changes to the bonus plan, they make approximately $45 per lease. Less pay and more work for a measly $45 bucks per lease? Make it, make sense. Community managers receive no proper training and are unskilled in human relations. The company will only promote employees in "workplace cliques." If you are a quiet, intelligent, and a hard worker, you will NOT get promoted. If you are highly extroverted, a know-it-all, and like to dabble in brown-nosing and gossip, then BINGO, you'll get promoted. Employees who have been at the company for years, who apply for a promotion will most likely not get selected. title: Not A Company I Could Recommend

I was also excited to have Sundays off and be a part of a company that I could grow in. Fast forward a couple years later and the only word that comes to mind is disappointment. Prior to Avalon, I had a clear idea of my "road map to success" and upper management was amazing. I could call her for anything and she genuinely cared about me not just as an employee but as a person. Upper management here left something to be desired to say the least. I consider myself a team player and love to do what is needed to reach a goal but I felt unmotivated at this company. Having quarterly meetings was simply a ra-ra show and the things that mattered were pushed behind. Things as simple as employees having a clear road map toward moving up in the company were talked about but never executed during my time there. I watched exceptional employees question their worth because individuals in upper management didn't really see the importance of knowing their employees in their region. I found myself seeing Avalonbay more and more like a job instead of a career and I knew if I wanted to grow in the way that I wanted, I would need to look elsewhere. The only thing that kept me there were my managers at my communities and the individuals I worked with on a daily basis. My experience with them was phenomenal and If I were to base my review off of them, it would be a different story. I also think a big con is the lack of compassionate for the residents that the staff deals with on a daily basis. Avalon is like any other big company and it is all about the bottom line. Resident retention was not that important even though it made more sense to keep someone in their apartment as opposed to paying the money to turn it or risking an apartment remaining vacant for months. One of the best things I experienced was forming great relationships with individuals and one of the worst was having to watch people leave a community they called home (for as long as 20 years in some cases) because the numbers from a system didn't work in their favor. We had residents that were retired, living on a fixed income, and getting ridiculous increases. While I understand the business side, it is very different when you have to be the one being yelled out or watching someone cry because they can no longer make ends meet. Unfortunately, the list can go on of why I chose to move on and I would not personally recommend this company from my experiences .

title: Very disappointed
pros: Very organized processes and policies. Lots of company sponsored lunches known affectionately as associate appreciation. If you want to learn how to spin and fake it until you make it this would be a great place to start out. Tons of google and glass door reviews for you to read through if you're looking to get some direction on if it's worth it or not. This goes for residents and employees.
cons: Nepotism is like a widespread disease there. No support from management it's an every man for himself kind of environment. Bonus/commissions system is designed to get the maximum amount of work/production out of you for the least amount of money. They set lofty and often times blatantly unattainable goals and act surprised when employees don't achieve them and subsequently don't get paid commissions or bonuses. This includes both the management and maintenance sides of the business. This is seen in areas such as NPS scores, leasing/renewal bonuses/Mid Lease surveys/ORM goals etc. If you enjoy being treated like a product, commodity, or an easily expendable asset of low value this is the place for you. Policy is king here but only where it serves someone's agenda, usually someone in management. There is NO accountability so more tenured employees get away with murder because they know they can. They will teach you to "act like an owner" and be "autonomous" however every time you do your decisions or actions will be called into question. Too many chiefs and not enough Indians to put it simply. If a resident has an issue with a rule/policy/fee all they have to do is threaten to contact the media or an attorney and Avalon will give them whatever they desire so good luck enforcing anything that is contested. They collect top dollar in rents, nickel and dime the extra fees and have astronomical rent increases. Try having conversation after conversation explaining to residents that they have a 15/18/20/25/30% rent increase for their same old apartment which hasn't all of a sudden learned a new trick and morphed into the Ritz Carlton. They build with the CHEAPEST materials they can find from china and the like and do not care about the quality provided to residents. Read some resident google reviews and notice a common thread about high rent increases, noise complaints, move out charges, cheap, looks good at first, not worth the money, buyer beware etc. They will quickly try to cover up any discrepancies or mistakes and routinely mislead residents or falsify information to avoid exposure such as issues with bugs, smoking, noise, "mildew or discoloration" aka MOLD. That's just a glimpse into some of the fun things you will enjoy with your belly full of "associate appreciation" aka "free food". Keep in mind Avalon Bay is a top real estate investment trust or REIT and they can afford it but it's a tax write off just like that 20% associate housing discount. They are raking in $2-5 billion annually according to Glassdoor and their premier "Pro" amongst a hefty list of Cons if you read the other reviews is "good food". What I will say is that if you are looking to build your resume this would be a great pit stop as it is a brand name. Like most brand names there is a certain level of buyer ignorance that goes hand and hand with brand recognition. Many places will hire you simply from seeing the Avalon name on your resume because Avalon Bay has an expert marketing department which knows that image is everything so they make sure everyone at the company is drinking the Koolaid so to speak. If you don't drink up then you don't last. If you last you recruit others to drink the koolaid too. Rinse and repeat. Fold in some act responsibly Spirit of caring code of ethics propaganda and there you have it. As someone else said in a previous review to describe the experience perfectly...STEP RIGHT UP AND JOIN THE CIRCUS! Good luck

title: More of The Same, But From One of The Best...
pros: On-site Teams - have the potential to be truly great. On-site managers have the ability to create a positive work environment, and buy lots of food for everyone. Customer Focus - for the most part we are empowered to make resident's lives better, assist with issues that come up, and close the loop. In most cases, were I an apartment renter, I'd absolutely rent with AvalonBay. WAG, fit, etc. - promoting basics makes sure on-site teams are delivering with a sense of consistency, and are being held accountable by residents. New Ideas - they will try almost anything, but don't adopt immediately. Values and Norms - on paper, these are great. They actually line up pretty much with what I believe in, so it makes it a bit easier. Colleagues - many people in your same role are decent, helpful, and fun people. You can always reach out, and bounce ideas off of them.
cons: I spent a few weeks rewriting this review, as I didn't want it to be knee-jerk, or completely negative, the one star is because most of the dissatisfaction comes down to decisions, which ultimately are ill conceived, and improperly executed. I believe these decision points are when the true test of our character is revealed, oftentimes the end result is safe, regressive, and benefits only a few. I write this part with a bit of a broken heart, and a somewhat foolish idea that this feedback could make a difference... I can't imagine it's like this just on the West Coast. Big on Phrases - not so much on action, or acknowledgement ("Keep doing what you're doing.", "Thank you for all that you do."), when you hear that, and you're not moving anywhere in the company, it sends mixed messages. These are usually said at large company events, or in passing in the rare occasion your superior takes time to meet with you. The first time you hear it, it makes you feel good, after that, it's just empty words coming from someone who doesn't really understand what it is that you do. Experience vs. Development - experience is sought in lieu of actual development. Upper management would much rather have you tread water, and struggle rather than actually teach you something, or help you develop into a new role. I guess through this struggle you "develop" into a better associate? Maybe, but focusing skills, and incorporating new ideas is also pretty key. They claim to have talent meetings, but haven't seen much come from them. Developing yourself is pretty much the only thing you've got, besides trainings, and meetings that don't offer much. Others have mentioned they're good at counseling which is true, but coaching is almost non-existent, and counseling without coaching is pointless. Tenure - is a key factor in promotions. If you've been there a while, they kind of just "take care of you". If you actually contribute, and work hard, and are looking for that promotion, you can actually be better than another candidate with more tenure, and tenure seems to trump, have observed this many times. It's easy to choose something familiar, but paying attention to what someone is actually doing in terms of output is a bit more important. Political, or personal decisions are made in promotions, but management is too scared to actually acknowledge this, and makes up a reason so far from the truth to explain it. When this happens, it leaves you frustrated, and conflicted. Just be real with people. Compensation Plan Rollout - sales goals, and metrics were introduced. Overall a great, and logical idea. One of the more progressive moves AVB had made. Part of this was that Sales and Service Supervisors were given a target dollar amount once the community goal was hit, but there wasn't clarification as to whether they would get individual payouts for leases they actually got themselves. Since this wasn't obvious, or spelled out, the company sent out a "reminder" email (not sure how you pass it off as a reminder if it's the first time you're hearing about it) stating an SSS would NOT be eligible for individual bonuses. This upset a lot of people, rightly so. It's money. It's their livelihood. No one acknowledged the error, and just acted as if. A simple apology would have gone a long way. Bad Management Decisions - have seen some absolute monsters be put in charge of communities, and/or other managers as directors. When I say monsters, I mean people with pure ego, no people skills whatsoever, and engage in behavior that caused associates to leave the company. It's true. They do personality assessments upon hire, but in many cases people must just be ignoring the results, or they're not very telling. Had a manager who rarely ever put their phone down, even when having a conversation with me. Colleagues - tying into the above, have had conversations with colleagues that left me questioning why they're here. They say very mean, and inconsiderate things about their staff, but do nothing to engage them. They also feel that associates should just "know" things, instead of taking the time to lead by example and actually teach, and engage them. Packages - the company's response to the absolutely overwhelming demand has been sluggish, and an afterthought. They claim to have knowledge of future trends, etc., but didn't see e-commerce coming? Even as they're building new communities? Get ready to be blamed, get yelled at, and receive non-stop calls and emails asking where the package that hasn't been delivered yet is, if you can leave it out, or other accommodations. They heavily downplay this problem, it bogs staff down, when they should be focusing on sales goals, and other, more meaningful customer service. Podding - they claim it's for "development" and "growth" purposes, but it's really just to save money on a salary, and make some poor soul's life miserable. They do it to the most nonsensical properties too. It's bad for business, bad for coverage, and bad for residents. Not all, but most. Politics - perhaps egotics is better to say. If you don't buy into the absolute BS (and that's what it is, it's not strategy, or anything like that) that your POD is selling you, then they make certain to punish you by simply ignoring you. The egos about are fragile, but in full-force. I've rarely seen a decision made that actually is based on merits, and logic. Every company has a clique, AVB is no exception. They preach about results, but don't base many decisions upon them. If you're into that kind of culture, and can stomach it, then go for it.
